2. Acidic Nature of Carboxylic Acids
acidic nature of R-COOH : stability of R-COO-
proportional to
(Iâˆ’,Râˆ’)(I^- , R^-)(Iâˆ’,Râˆ’)ï»¿/(I+,R+)/ (I^+, R^+)/(I+,R+)ï»¿
more the more -I more stable it is
All of the below are for acidic comparisions (which is more acidic)
Decreasing order of -I effect based on number of C-atoms
Because in the meta st
OCH3 will dominate normal CH3
for 5th - generally the A should be more acidic but there is an exception based on experimental data which says the order to be B>A>C>D
Why did we not consider +R effect in 5th?
Because Halogens...
A has more bad +I because CH3 is more closer to COOH
The actual order is different than than the experimental order because of Ortho Effect
According to Ortho Effect, ortho substituted benzoic acid is always more acidic than its meta and para isomer and also benzoic acid (normal one - for 95% of the cases)
When a substituent is in ortho position, the big COOH group will go in other plane than the plane of Benzene. That plane will be such way that resonance effect will not be there. Hence, it is more acidic.
It is only for benzoic acid
.
Ortho will by default be the first one and then simple see -I and +R effect
